reasoning: The critique targets a key support for the paper’s “eutopia is fragile/narrow target” conclusion: the move from a long menu of putative moral failure modes to a quasi-multiplicative rarity/fragility picture (Section 2→2.4). If the failure modes are substantially correlated or reducible to a few deep variables, that would weaken the justification for treating ‘mostly-great’ futures as requiring many independent successes. However, the critique only sketches the coupling claim and doesn’t argue that the underlying ‘deep variables’ are themselves easy to steer, nor that correlation is strong enough to materially change the implied probability mass near the top. Also, a substantial part of the paper’s case (Section 3 on bounded/unbounded/fussy value functions) can sustain “no easy eutopia” even if the Section 2 list is somewhat double-counted. Relevance is moderate: it engages a Tier-2 core working assumption (narrow eutopian target/product-of-factors framing) and suggests a concrete place where the argument may overstate independence, but it doesn’t directly resolve one of Forethought’s Tier-3 live disputes.
title: "Moral Catastrophes Aren't as Independent as They Seem"
